wiki.text:
In computer programming, a 'subroutine' is a sequence of program instructions
that perform a specific task, packaged as a unit. This unit can then be used in
programs wherever that particular task should be performed. Subprograms may be
defined within programs, or separately in libraries that can be used by
multiple programs.

In different programming languages a subroutine may be called a 'procedure', a
'function', a 'routine', a '[[method (computing)|method]]', or a 'subprogram'.
The generic term 'callable unit' is sometimes used.<ref>{{Cite web |author= U.S.
Election Assistance Commission |title= Definitions of Words with Special
Meanings |work= Voluntary Voting System Guidelines |date= |year= 2007 |url=
http://www.eac.gov/vvsg/glossary.aspx |accessdate= 2013-01-14 |authorlink=
Election Assistance Commission}}</ref>

As the name subprogram suggests, a subroutine behaves in much the same way as a
computer program that is used as one step in a larger program or another
subprogram. A subroutine is often coded so that it can be started (called)
several times and/or from several places during one execution of the program,
including from other subroutines, and then branch back (return) to the next
instruction after the call once the subroutine's task is done.

Maurice Wilkes, David Wheeler, and Stanley Gill are credited with the invention
of this concept, which they termed a closed subroutine,<ref></ref><ref>{{cite
book |last1= Wilkes |first1= M. V. |last2= Wheeler |first2= D. J. |last3= Gill
|first3=S. |title= Preparation of Programs for an Electronic Digital Computer
|publisher= Addison-Wesley |year= 1951 }}</ref> contrasted with an open
subroutine or macro.<ref></ref>

Subroutines are a powerful programming tool,<ref name="knuth1"></ref> and the
syntax of many programming languages includes support for writing and using
them. Judicious use of subroutines (for example, through the structured
programming approach) will often substantially reduce the cost of developing and
maintaining a large program, while increasing its quality and reliability.<ref
name="structprog"></ref> Subroutines, often collected into libraries, are an
important mechanism for sharing and trading software. The discipline of object-
oriented programming is based on objects and methods (which are subroutines
attached to these objects or object classes).

In the compiling method called threaded code, the executable program is
basically a sequence of subroutine calls.
wiki.title: Subroutine
